set_params(**params)[source]¶

Set the parameters of this estimator.

The method works on simple estimators as well as on nested objects (such as Pipeline). The latter have parameters of the form <component>__<parameter> so that it’s possible to update each component of a nested object.

Parameters:

**params (dict) – Estimator parameters.

Returns:

self – Estimator instance.

Return type:

estimator instance

weelex.ensemble module¶

class weelex.ensemble.AugmentedEnsemble(category, categories, outside_categories, n_models=10, n_samples_multiplier=5, n_samples_multiplier_outside=5, input_shape=300, modeltype='svm', pca=False, svc_c=1.0, svc_kernel='rbf', progress_bar=False, n_vectors_agg_training=3, run_fast=False, random_state=None, **modelkwargs)[source]¶

Bases: BaseEnsemble, BaseEstimator

Class to train an ensemble of models. For each model, a random selection of input vectors is aggregated as a linear combination to “augment” the data.

Parameters:

BaseEstimator – Sklearn base class for estimators.

draw_random_samples_classwise(X: DataFrame, y: DataFrame, classvalue: int, n_samples_multiplier: int = 5, n_samples: Optional[int] = None, include_all_original: bool = True) → Tuple[ndarray, ndarray][source]¶

Combine word vectors by randomly selecting terms of a specific category and making a linear combination of these

Parameters:

  • X (pandas.DataFrame) – The matrix of word vectors

  • y (pandas.DataFrame) – Contains the classes of each term

  • classvalue (int) – Value of current class to consider. 0 or 1

  • n_samples_multiplier (int) – Value to multiply number of original words of the category with to get the number of observations that shall be drawn.

  • n_samples (int, optional) – Number of samples. Defaults to None.

  • include_all_original (bool, optional) – Whether the original, i.e. non-aggregated, word vectors shall be included in the sample. Defaults to True.

Returns:

The X and y arrays that can be used

for input in Machine Learning models.

Return type:

numpy.ndarray, numpy.ndarray

fit(X, y)[source]¶

Method to train the ml models via passed X and y arrays. X is a matrix with the embedding vectors for each term, y is a binary that tells whether the term belongs to the “inside” (i.e. is part of the category that shall be predicted) or the “outside” (i.e. is from a category different from the one to be predicted).

A sample of observations, in the form of linear combinations from random word embeddings of a category, is drawn and used for training.

Parameters:

  • X (numpy.array or pandas.DataFrame) – Matrix of word embeddings

  • y (numpy.array or pandas.DataFrame) – target values

load(filename)[source]¶

Load (hyper-)parameters and models that were saved using the .save method.

Parameters:

filename (str) – Name of saved file

predict(X, cutoff=0.5)[source]¶

Predict binary class of input matrix. Uses .predict_proba method.

Parameters:

  • X (array-like) – Input matrix

  • cutoff (float, optional) – Cutoff value for binary prediction. Defaults to 0.5.

Returns:

Binary prediction

Return type:

numpy.array

predict_proba(X)[source]¶

Method to predict “probabilities” for each observation. Mean of probabilites for individual models.

Parameters:

X (numpy.array or pandas.DataFrame) – Matrix to predict

Returns:

Prediction vector containing the probabilities

Return type:

numpy.array

save(filename)[source]¶

Save (hyper-)parameters and models to disk. Use this to use a fitted model later on for prediction.

Parameters:

filename (str) – Path and name of save file.

score(X, y, score_func=<function f1_score>)[source]¶

Scoring function. Used for Parameter tuning

Parameters:

  • X (array-like) – Input matrix

  • y (array-like) – target vector

  • score_func (callable, optional) – Function for scoring. Defaults to sklearn.metrics.f1_score.

Returns:

Score

Return type:

float

weelex.ensemble.make_agg_sample(X: ndarray, n: int = 3) → ndarray[source]¶
Draw n vectors randomly and return the linear

combination of these with random weights. Method to ensure npdarraothe vectors add up to 1 is simplified by just drawing random integers and taking their relative size.

Parameters:

  • X (numpy.array) – n-m Matrix with data to draw from.

  • n (int) – Number of vectors to aggregate.

Returns:

Vector with linear combination of shape (m,).

i.e. is only one observation.

Return type:

numpy.array

weelex.lexicon module¶

Bases: object

copy()[source]¶
embed(embeddings) → None[source]¶
property embedding_shape¶
property embeddings¶
get_vocabulary() → list[source]¶

Returns a sorted list of all the lexicon categories

Example

>>> my_dct = {'Food': ['Bread', 'Salad'], 'Animal': ['Dog', 'Cat']}
>>> l = BaseLexicon(my_dct)
>>> l.get_vocabulary()
['Bread', 'Cat', 'Dog', 'Salad']
Returns:

Sorted array of categories

Return type:

list

property is_embedded: bool¶
property keys¶

to_dict() → dict[source]¶

Return the lexicon in dictionary format.

Example

>>> my_dct = {'A': ['a', 'b'], 'B': ['c', 'd']}
>>> l = BaseLexicon(my_dct)
>>> l.to_dict()
{'A': ['a', 'b'], 'B': ['c', 'd']}
Returns:

dict with the lexicon key-value pairs

Return type:

dict
